title-group.article-title: Acute Poisonings, Suicidality and Systemic Inflammatory Load in Pregnant Women

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Family Medicine, Harran University Faculty of Medicine, Şanlıurfa, Türkiye
2Department of Emergency Medicine, Harran University Faculty of Medicine, Şanlıurfa, Türkiye

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Koçakoğlu Ş, e-mail: senaykocakoglu@yahoo.com

fn.p: Cite this article as: Koçakoğlu Ş, Buyukaslan H. Acute poisonings, suicidality and systemic inflammatory load in pregnant women. Psychiatry Clin Psychopharmacol. 2025;35(2):141-148.

license.license-p: Content of this journal is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Pregnancy can be challenging for women in various manners and can boost the risk of intentional self-poisonings. The aim of the study is to evaluate the occurrence and clinical characteristics of poisonings and the relationship between suicidal tendency and increased systemic inflammatory load during pregnancy.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This study was performed in a tertiary hospital emergency department using 10 years of data. The study covered 69 female individuals, 35 pregnant and 34 non-pregnant, with acute poisoning diagnoses. The cases’ sociodemographic and clinical features, as well as routine blood results, were evaluated. The neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) and platelet-to-lymphocyte ratio (PLR) markers were calculated to assess systemic inflammatory load.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The intentional suicide rate in pregnant women was 85.71% (n = 30). Pregnant individuals had significantly higher PLR (P < .001) and NLR (P = .001) levels compared to the control group. The NLR values in intentional poisonings and the PLR in accidental poisonings were found to be proportionally higher, but the difference between both groups was not statistically significant (P = .448 and P = .701, respectively).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The vast majority of acute poisonings in pregnant women were intentional. Although the inflammatory burden values were significantly higher in pregnant women than in controls, there was not enough strong evidence to establish a link between increased inflammatory burden and suicidal tendencies in pregnant women.

funding-group.funding-statement: The authors declare that this study received no financial support.

list-item.p: There is still a gap in the field of studies focusing on understanding the pathophysiology and clinical features of poisonings during pregnancy, which threaten the lives of both mother and fetus.

Some studies in different populations have reported a link between increased inflammatory load and suicidality, and this study appears to be the first in this regard in the pregnant population. The majority of acute poisonings in pregnant women were due to suicidal purposes. Although PLR and NLR levels of pregnant individuals were significantly higher than in the control group, no significant relationship was found between increased inflammatory load and suicidal tendencies in the pregnant population.

High awareness and close follow-up against the possibility of acute poisoning and suicide attempts can be life-saving for pregnant women who apply to the emergency department even with complaints such as nausea and vomiting, which are thought to be simple and specific to pregnancy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Acute poisoning, which is one of the most common reasons for admission to emergency services, can occur accidentally or intentionally. Intentional self-harm poisonings are among the leading causes of suicide-related deaths.1-3 Although many studies have been conducted on acute poisoning cases that impose a psychological and economic burden on individuals and the healthcare system,4-9 studies aimed at understanding the occurrence and pathophysiology of poisoning in pregnant women are limited.10-13.
In case of unplanned and unwanted pregnancy, the woman may feel helpless, and therefore pregnancy may cause mental disorders and be a risk factor for suicidal self-poisoning.14

A poisoning incident that occurs during pregnancy is even more serious than others because it affects the health of both the mother and the fetus. The reported mortality rate in pregnant women following poison exposure is 3 times that of non-pregnant women because of the complications.15

The immune response adapts during pregnancy toward various agents and facilitates maternal–fetal tolerance by an excellent course.16 A remarkable increase of regulatory T cells such as cluster of differantiation (CD) 4 and CD25, macrophages, natural killer cells, and anti-inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-10 is reported to occur to prevent autoimmunity, to support placental development, and to activate labor.17-19 The amount of leukocytes was shown to increase and show intense invasion of the uterus from the first moments of pregnancy until the remodeling of the cervix after birth.20

Given some guiding research linking increased inflammatory burden to mental issues such as suicidality, it is conceivable that the expected increased inflammatory burden during pregnancy may also be a risk factor for suicidality.21 The link between inflammatory burden and suicidality was defined through hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis interactions and serotonin precursors by Ryan and Oquendo.21 Studies have shown an association between increased systemic inflammatory burden and mental problems. Major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia were found to be related to the increased amount of systemic inflammatory load and measured by biomarkers.22-24 Neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio was first defined to be a potential biomarker for suicidal tendency.25 Although some studies that have defined reference values of systemic inflammatory load calculated by such biomarkers have been referred, none was found examining the influence of inflammatory load on suicidal tendency of pregnant women.26,27 The presented study seems to be the first in this regard. According to this study’s hypothesis, increased inflammatory load during pregnancy is associated with suicidal tendency. In this study, besides demographic and clinical characteristics and occurrence of acute poisonings, it is focused on the relationship between suicidal tendency and systemic inflammatory load on pregnant population.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: The study was approved by Harran University Clinical Research Ethics Committee (September 18, 2023 / 23.17.24).

sec.title: Data Sources and Participants
sec.p: The universe of the study was pregnant and non-pregnant patients who applied to Harran University Hospital Emergency Department and diagnosed acute poisoning between September 2013 and September 2023. Since Harran University Hospital is the center where such serious pregnant cases are transmitted in the region, the study was planned as a single center in Şanlıurfa city. Among all of the poisoning cases on hospital registry system, there were 36 pregnant women diagnosed with acute poisoning within 10 years. As a control group, non-pregnant women with poisoning diagnoses were selected by simple random sampling method. Exclusion criteria were defined as incomplete data, having an autoimmune disease or any chronic infection history or an acute infection at the time of admission (e.g. urinary tract infection) taken from patients and or their relatives, based on analysis results and thoroughly researched recorded data. One out of the patients in the control group and one out of the pregnants were excluded due to having urinary infection detected from urine test results at registration. A total of 69 patients, 35 pregnant and 34 non-pregnant, were included in the study (Figure 1). All of those cases were transferred to intensive care unit and were followed up for a while after emergency department.

sec.title: Measures and Parameters
sec.p: After scanning the literature on the research topic, a sociodemographic-clinical data evaluation form was created by the researchers. The patients’ data were collected through this form. Detailed clinical information and basic demographics of the patients which were recorded at the registry time through e-medulla system, through their relatives, review of their history, bedside physical examination, and diagnostic tests (serum drug concentrations, routine urine and blood tests and, toxic tests). The patients’ pregnancy diagnoses were confirmed at the registry by blood test and ultrasonography and results were reached on through hospital electronic registration system.

The following parameters were measured from routine blood samples taken at the time of presentation to the emergency department: white blood cells (WBC), hemoglobin (Hgb), lymphocytes, neutrophils, platelets, mean corpuscular volume (MCV), aspartate transferase, alanine transaminase, amylase, calcium, albumin, sodium, potassium, prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, and C-reactive protein (CRP). The ratios of neutrophils to lymphocytes (NLR) and platelets to lymphocytes (PLR), which have been identified as markers of the level of systemic inflammation, were also computed. Both NLR and PLR were computed by dividing the total number of neutrophils by lymphocytes and the number of platelets by lymphocytes, respectively.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Frequency (n) and percentage (%) values are given in the definition of categorical variables. In the descriptive statistics of continuous variables, mean ± SD or median (IQR) were given according to distribution characteristics. Normality assumptions of the variables were examined by Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. Mann–Whitney U-test was used for the comparison of non-normally distributed continuous variables between 2 groups. Independent Sample t-est was used in cases where the normality assumption was met. For normally distributed variables descriptive statistics are given as mean ± SD. If it was not a normal distribution, it was given as median (IQR). The categorical variables were compared by chi-square/Fisher’s exact test. IBM SPSS 25 (IBM SPSS Corp.; Armonk, NY, USA) program was used in all analyses and P < .05 was accepted as significance level.

sec.title: Sociodemographic Clinical Features
sec.p: The data from 69 patients, 35 (50.7%) pregnant and 34 (49.3%) non-pregnant, were evaluated. Pregnant and non-pregnant women differed significantly in terms of their marital status (P < .001), total number of pregnancies (P < .001), and history of mental illness (P < .001) (Table 1).

sec.title: Parameters Related to Acute Poisoning
sec.p: Of the 69 poisoning cases, 61 were intentional suicides. Rates were similar between pregnants (n = 30, 49.2%) and non-pregnants (n = 31, 50.8%) (P = .710), The most common reason of poisoning in pregnant women is multiple drug intake (n = 17, 56.7%), and in non-pregnant women, psychiatric drugs (n = 7, 77.8%) (Table 2).

sec.title: Symptoms Related to Acute Poisoning
sec.p: Among symptoms, nausea and vomiting rates were significantly higher in the control group (P = .011, P = .553). Vomiting was the most common symptom in pregnancies but the rate of this symptom was higher in the control group and there was no significant difference between the 2 groups (P = .553) (Table 3).

sec.title: Laboratory Parameters
sec.p: As shown in Table 4, there were significant differences between the groups with WBC (P = .002), neutrophil (P < .001), amylase (P = .040), CRP (P < .001), PLR (P < .001), and NLR (P = .001) values were significantly higher in pregnant women. Red blood cells (P = .007), lymphocyte (P < .001), BUN (P < .001), creatinine (P = .026), GGT (P = .019), CK (P = .003), albumin (P = .003), and sodium (P < .001) values were statistically significantly higher in non-pregnant women.

sec.title: Suicidality-Related Analysis
sec.p: Table 5 shows the results of the comparative analysis of accidental and suicidal poisonings with NLR and PLR parameters in both groups. The NLR rate in suicidal poisonings and the PLR in accidental poisonings were proportionally high, but the difference between the groups was not statistically significant (P = .448, P = .701 respectively).

In pregnant group, NLR value rate in suicidal poisonings and the PLR in accidental poisonings were found to be proportionally higher, but the difference between the groups was not statistically significant (P = .981, P = .300 respectively) (Table 6).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Poisoning during pregnancy is a severe circumstance that necessitates prompt assessment and treatment and studies aimed at understanding the occurrence and pathophysiology of poisonings during pregnancy are still limited.15 The results of the presented study showed that almost all poisonings in pregnant women were for suicidal purposes. Similarly, first study conducted on this subject in Türkiye found that the majority of poisonings in pregnant women were caused by suicide attempts.10 Eyasu et al28 also reported that the majority of acute poisonings in pregnant and non-pregnant women were caused by intentional self-poisoning. The high rate of suicide attempts in this study (88.57%) may be related to the high rate of unplanned and undesired pregnancies in Şanlıurfa, which has the highest fertility rate in Türkiye, as well as difficult living circumstances and women do not receive enough support. In this study, it was observed that poisoning cases in both pregnant and non-pregnant groups were distributed between ages of 21-34, similar to the literature.10,28 Young women who may experience financial problems, family discord and who have less experience in dealing with difficulties may need to be supported with counseling and training on relevant issues.

The majority of the women during pregnancy with suicidal attempt were reported to be in the first trimester according to the literature.10,29 Although the distribution of suicide attempt is proportionally equal in the first and second trimesters, due to the small number of participants, the relationship between suicide and pregnancy trimester could not be evaluated in this study. It is difficult to understand how a woman can commit suicide even though she is pregnant. It can be related to unhappy marriages, unwanted pregnancies, and mental disorders. If there is unrest, especially violence between spouses, women’s mental health may deteriorate. As unwanted and unplanned pregnancies increase, they will look for ways to escape from the crisis and may turn to suicide as a last resort. It seems that sustainable training should be planned for couples on family counseling and birth control, and their material and spiritual needs should be sensitive.

The relationship between psychiatric diseases and intentional poisonings has been shown in previous studies.29 In the systematic review conducted by Favril et al30 on 37 case-control studies from 23 countries, suicide cases were evaluated and they found that mental disorders and self-harm history increased the risk 10 times more than others. The history of psychiatric disorders in the pregnant group was significantly lower than of control group. Similarly, it was reported in the literature that the rate of having a previous history of psychiatric disease was significantly lower in pregnant women with self-poisoning.31 These findings suggest that being pregnant may be a risk factor for suicide, independent of previous mental health problems.

In this study, all cases were followed up in intensive care after emergency intervention, and there was not any difference between the groups in terms of length of stay. Paudyal reported the average hospital stay as 7.7 days. In those with organophosphate poisoning, the number of days were longer and is 10.2 days. In the same study, the mortality rate was found to be 5%.20 The rate of fatal suicide attempts during pregnancy reported by Czeizel32 is much lower (0.4-6.7%). In the presented study, none of the suicidal poisoning cases resulted in death. Women may use suicide attempts as a means of attracting attention in desperation because they cannot establish healthy communication with their husbands and family elders.

Considering that the biggest risk factor in suicides is a previous suicide attempt and can be completed with a repeated attempt, the need for closer follow-up and support of this group should be taken into consideration. A recent study from Mexico city on follow up of suicide attempters and control group after discharging from hospital for 3 months revealed that 5.21% of participants showed some suicidal behaviors during that period.33 Furthermore another study revealed that 40% of those who died due to suicide had previously attempted suicide.34 Several studies revealed that poisoning/self poisoning can occur in many different ways, but most commonly occurs with drugs (psychiatric drugs and painkillers) and alcohol.10,35,36 Drugs were the most common reason of poisoning in pregnants in this study. There was a higher history of psychiatric illness and there was a significantly higher intake of psychiatric drugs in the control group. Eyasu et al28 reported differently that bleach and organophosphates were the most common poisoning sources. Poisoning/self-poisonings in Türkiye, especially with analgesics, may constitute a separate risk factor for poisoning in all age groups in the general population, as these drugs can be purchased without a prescription.

According to this findings, vomiting, nausea, and abdominal pain were the most common complaints in pregnant women. These symptoms which are considered simple dyspeptic complaints or pregnancy-specific findings should bring poisoning to mind, especially in emergency admissions in pregnant women.37

Nowadays NLR, PLR, and CRP, which are indicators of systemic inflammatory load have been argued as potential biomarkers of suicidal behavior.25 Velasco et al25 revealed that NLR could be used to predict suicidal risk in patients with severe major depressive disorder patients. Ivković et al38 and Capuzzi et al39 also reported that NLR is valuable in predicting suicidal behavior in some mental disorders. In the present study, both NLR and PLR values were proportionally higher in suicidal poisonings in non-pregnant women. Ekinci and Ekinci40 found NLR and CRP levels to be quite higher in patients with suicide attempters group. Gibbs et al41 also reported that increased CRP level was associated with suicidal attempts and mortality and the odds ratio of attempting suicide increased by 1.27% when CRP increased by 2.7 times. In presented study, CRP values were found to be significantly higher in the pregnant group, but no significant relationship could be established between CRP and suicidal tendency.

Recently, studies focused on NLR and PLR during pregnancy were found to be related to recurrent pregnancy loss and abortion, pre-eclampsia, gestational diabetes, and some cancers and these fast and practical markers seem to remain popular for further researches.42-45 In this study, NLR in pregnant suicidal poisoning cases and PLR in pregnant accidental poisoning cases were found to be proportionally higher than non-pregnants but the difference between the groups was not significant (P = .981, P = .300 respectively).

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: One weakness was that there was no control group of pregnant women who did not attempt suicide. It would be relevant to compare inflammatory marker levels among pregnant women who attempted suicide vs. pregnant women who were not suicidal.

It would be more accurate if the patients with previous history of psychiatric illness were excluded. This study is single centered and number of patients who match inclusion critera are limited and this enabled the researchers to make some comparisions and to research from different centers with higher number of patients who can provide stronger evidence. However, hopefully the findings of this study will increase awareness on this issue and contribute to future studies.

In conclusion given the high rate of poisonings due to suicide attempt among total cases, there appears to be a need for strategies to improve negative conditions that may lead to suicide so this challenging period can be overcome more easier. Perhaps the most important step is effective counselling about contraceptive use to prevent unwanted pregnancies. Common mental health disorders such as depression and anxiety should be detected using valid scales and be managed through professional consultations with psychologists and psychiatrists. Pregnant women should be encouraged to seek help from their family members, spouses, and healthcare personnel. Suggesting local governments and organizations to expand aid package support during and after pregnancy may have a positive impact on predicaments where financial problems are the main issue. Closer follow-up is more needed in this group of patients, as frequent and nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and hypotension may be considered as pregnancy-specific and overlooked. According to this study results, although the inflammatory biomarker values were significantly higher in pregnant women than in controls, there was not enough strong evidence to establish a link between increased inflammatory burden and suicidal tendencies in pregnant women.

fn.p: Ethics Committee Approval: This study was approved by Ethics Committee of Harran University, (Approval No: 23.17.24, Date: September 18.2023).

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The datasets can be available from authors on a reasonable request.

Comparison of Sociodemographic and Clinical Characteristics Between Pregnant and Non-Pregnant Groups
